explanation: Ovulation occurs and the uterus prepares for implantation. No embryo exists yet.
Fertilization typically happens this week. A zygote forms and begins dividing.
The blastocyst implants in the uterine lining. Hormone hCG is now produced.
The embryo forms 3 layers—ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm. Placenta begins forming.
The heart starts beating and basic facial features begin to form.
Arm and leg buds appear. Neural tube closes to form the spinal cord.
Hands and feet start to develop. Brain and facial features are becoming more defined.
The embryo has webbed fingers and toes. Major organs are forming.
All essential organs have begun forming. The tail is disappearing.
The embryo becomes a fetus. Vital organs continue to grow and function.
Fingers and toes separate. Tooth buds and nail beds form.
The fetus moves spontaneously. Reflexes begin to develop.
Vocal cords form. Intestines move into the abdomen.
The baby's gender may be visible. Lanugo, fine hair, begins to form.
Bones continue to harden. Baby can make facial expressions.
The baby can hear sounds. Circulatory and urinary systems are functioning.
Fat stores begin developing. Skeleton continues to harden.
The baby can yawn and hiccup. Nervous system is maturing.
Sensory development advances. Baby can hear and respond to sounds.
Halfway through pregnancy. Baby's movement can often be felt now.
Digestive system practicing functions. Baby swallows amniotic fluid.
Lungs developing rapidly. Baby begins to develop sleep patterns.
Taste buds develop. Baby may respond to light and sound.
Skin is becoming less translucent. Lungs and brain continue maturing.
Hearing is fully developed. Baby may respond to familiar voices.
Baby gains fat. Eyes begin to open and blink.
Nostrils open. Baby starts breathing amniotic fluid rhythmically.
Lung sacs develop. Eyelashes and eyebrows are fully formed.
Eyesight continues developing. Brain activity is detectable.
Fat layers form. Baby begins regulating body temperature.
Baby's bones are fully developed, though still soft.
Baby gains weight rapidly. Brain connections are forming quickly.
Baby starts to store minerals. Lanugo starts shedding.
Pupils can dilate. Immune system begins to strengthen.
Baby recognizes familiar voices. Skull bones remain soft.
Baby's position may shift head-down for birth.
Central nervous system and lungs mature further.
Baby practices breathing and sucking. Weight gain continues.
Baby's organs are ready for birth. Movements may slow down.
Baby is full term. Skin is pink and smooth.
Responds to loud sounds, stares at faces, moves head side to side. Reflexes like sucking and grasping dominate.
Begins to smile responsively, can briefly calm themselves, starts to follow things with eyes.
Raises head and chest during tummy time, coos and makes gurgling sounds, shows recognition of caregivers.
Begins to babble, pushes down on legs when feet are on hard surface, brings hands to mouth.
Rolls over from tummy to back, shows emotions like happiness and frustration, reaches for toys.
Rolls both ways, begins to sit with support, responds to own name.
Sits without support briefly, rocks back and forth on hands and knees, starts recognizing strangers.
Crawls, uses fingers to rake food, understands 'no'.
Pulls to stand, has favorite toys, uses thumb and finger to grasp.
Cruises while holding onto furniture, imitates gestures, finds hidden objects easily.
Says 'mama' and 'dada' specifically, follows simple directions, points with index finger.
May stand alone, starts using objects correctly (like cup, brush), repeats sounds or actions for attention.
Walks independently, drinks from a cup, points to show what they want.
Explores actively, says several single words, enjoys helping with chores.
Starts running, scribbles with crayon, shows increasing independence.
Says phrases like 'more milk', follows 2-step directions, throws ball overhand.
Can name items in a picture book, begins sorting shapes and colors, imitates behavior of others.
Speaks in short sentences, climbs onto furniture without help, starts pretend play with dolls/toys.
